What’s inside an ATO

Hugo Flávio

2025-09-07

Source: vignettes/articles/ATO-structure.qmd

Slot based data storage

The Animal Tracking Object (ATO) is an S4 object made of several slots. These were designed to be broadly applicable to tracking data of any kind (e.g. acoustic telemetry, satellite, radio). The slots are interconnected, so the ATO automatically checks e.g. which of your tags were detected or observed (different things, see below) throughout the study.

print(knitr::kable(sheets_data$slots))
slot defining class other classes optional classes
@det ATO_det data.frame data.table, tibble
@dep ATO_dep data.frame data.table, tibble
@tag ATO_tag data.frame data.table, tibble
@ani ATO_ani data.frame data.table, tibble
@obs ATO_obs data.frame data.table, tibble
@log ATO_log data.frame data.table, tibble
@tbl ATO_tbl character -

@ani

The animals slot contains information on the animals tracked.

x <- sheets_data$columns
x <- x[grep("@ani", unlist(x[, 1])), ]
x <- x[unlist(x[, 4]) == "manual", ]
x <- x[, -c(1, 4)]
print(knitr::kable(x))
column name (snake case) column type short description
` character name/code of the animal
capture_location character place where the animal was caught
capture_datetime POSIXct date and time when the animal was caught
capture_lat numeric latitude of the capture
capture_lon numeric longitude of the capture
release_location character place where the animal was released
release_datetime POSIXct date and time when the animal was released
release_lat numeric latitude of the release
release_lon numeric longitude of the release
… any non-standard column names are allowed

@tag

The tags slot contains information on the transmitters that were used to track the animals.

x <- sheets_data$columns
x <- x[grep("@tag", unlist(x[, 1])), ]
x <- x[unlist(x[, 4]) == "manual", ]
x <- x[, -c(1, 4)]
print(knitr::kable(x))
column name (snake case) column type short description
manufacturer character company that made the tag
model character model of the tag
power_level numeric power level of the tag
ping_rate numeric ping rate of the tag
ping_variation numeric +- variation added to individual pings
serial integer serial code of the tag
transmitter character transmitter code emitted by the tag
activation_datetime POSIXct activation date
battery_life numeric battery life
sensor_type character sensor type associated with the transmitter (e.g. temperature)
sensor_unit character units of the sensor data collected (e.g. C)
animal character name/code of the animal that received the tag
… any non-standard column names are allowed

The animal column will be matched against the animal names provided in the @ani slot.

@dep

The deployments slot contains information on autonomous, stationary receivers that were deployed to listen to the transmitters.

x <- sheets_data$columns
x <- x[grep("@dep", unlist(x[, 1])), ]
x <- x[unlist(x[, 4]) == "manual", ]
x <- x[, -c(1, 4)]
print(knitr::kable(x))
column name (snake case) column type short description
receiver_manufacturer character company that made the receiver
receiver_model character model of the receiver
receiver_serial integer serial code of the receiver (this is the column used to match deployments)
receiver_codeset character codeset of the receiver
transmitter character Can either be a beacon located inside a receiver, or a stationary reference transmitter
transmitter_manufacturer character company that made the transmitter
transmitter_ping_rate numeric ping rate of the transmitter
transmitter_model character model of the transmitter
transmitter_serial integer serial code of the transmitter
deploy_location character name of the location where the receiver was deployed
deploy_datetime POSIXct date and time of the deployment (yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss)
deploy_lat numeric latitude of the deployment
deploy_lon numeric longitude of the deployment
deploy_z numeric depth of the deployment (as measured from the reference surface of the waterbody)
recover_datetime POSIXct date and time of the recovery (yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss)
recover_lat numeric latitude of the recovery
recover_lon numeric longitude of the recovery
… any non-standard column names are allowed

@det

The detections slot contains the detection extracts obtained from the stationary receivers deployed.

x <- sheets_data$columns
x <- x[grep("@det", unlist(x[, 1])), ]
x <- x[unlist(x[, 4]) == "manual", ]
x <- x[, -c(1, 4)]
print(knitr::kable(x))
column name (snake case) column type short description
datetime POSIXct date and time of the detection (yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss)
frac_second numeric fraction of the second when the detection was received
receiver_serial integer serial number of the receiver that picked up the detection
transmitter character transmitter picked up
sensor_value numeric respective sensor value
… any non-standard column names are allowed

The receiver_serial column will be matched to the receivers listed in the @dep slot.

@obs

The observations slot contains records of direct and indirect observations of an animal or tag. For example, a photo of the tail of a whale is a direct observation of the animal. A reported capture of a fish by an angler is also a direct observation of the animal. On the other hand, a satellite-estimated position of a transmitter is an indirect observation of a tag. A detection of a tag using a mobile receiver is also an indirect observation of a tag. The choice between direct and indirect observation types declares the confidence you have on that observation. This information may be used by modelling tools to determine which positions to rely on more heavily.

x <- sheets_data$columns
x <- x[grep("@obs", unlist(x[, 1])), ]
x <- x[unlist(x[, 4]) == "manual", ]
x <- x[, -c(1, 4)]
print(knitr::kable(x))
column name (snake case) column type short description
animal character name/code of the observed animal
transmitter character transmitter detected
type character type of observation (e.g. manual tracking, visual, etc)
terminal logical does this observation mark the end of tracking for this animal
location character location of the observation
datetime POSIXct date and time of the observation
lat numeric latitude of the observation
lon numeric longitude of the observation
… any non-standard column names are allowed

The animal column is matched to the animal names in the @ani slot, while the tag column is matched to the transmitter column in the @tag slot. Observations typically only use one of the two columns.

@log

The log slot keeps track of the operations performed to the ATO since it was initialized to its current state. It is a great tool both for debugging and for increasing the reproducibility of animal tracking analyses.

x <- sheets_data$columns
x <- x[grep("@obs", unlist(x[, 1])), ]
x <- x[unlist(x[, 4]) == "manual", ]
x <- x[, -c(1, 4)]
print(knitr::kable(x))
column name (snake case) column type short description
animal character name/code of the observed animal
transmitter character transmitter detected
type character type of observation (e.g. manual tracking, visual, etc)
terminal logical does this observation mark the end of tracking for this animal
location character location of the observation
datetime POSIXct date and time of the observation
lat numeric latitude of the observation
lon numeric longitude of the observation
… any non-standard column names are allowed
